[Think Stats Chapter 3 Exercise 1](http://greenteapress.com/thinkstats2/html/thinkstats2004.html#toc31) (actual vs. biased)

Problem: use numkdhh to calculate the actual pmf for the number of children under 18 in a household as well as the biased pmf you would see if you surveyed the children.  
Solution: I used the ThinkStats functions to read in the respondent data and create the actual pmf:  
```python
resp = nsfg.ReadFemResp()
pmf = thinkstats2.Pmf(resp['numkdhh'], label='actual')
```
Then I used the BiasPmf function to calculate the biased pmf:  
```python
def BiasPmf(pmf, label):
    new_pmf = pmf.Copy(label=label)

    for x, p in pmf.Items():
        new_pmf.Mult(x, x)
        
    new_pmf.Normalize()
    return new_pmf  

biased_pmf = BiasPmf(pmf, label='biased')
```
Then I plotted the two on top of each other:
```python
thinkplot.PrePlot(2)
thinkplot.Pmfs([pmf, biased_pmf])
thinkplot.Config(xlabel='# of children under 18 in household', ylabel='PMF')
```
![biased v actual plot](data:image/png;base64,)  
Then I calculated the two means:  
```python
print('Actual mean', pmf.Mean())
print('Observed mean', biased_pmf.Mean())
Actual mean 1.024205155043831
Observed mean 2.403679100664282
```
